","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM1001","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM1001 - Introductory Chemistry","description":"

Introductory Chemistry is designed for students entering University with little or no previous background in Chemistry. The course will provide basic descriptions of atomic and molecular structure, nomenclature, the Periodic Table, stoichiometry, equilibrium, kinetics, common reaction types, acids and bases, and the fundamentals of organic chemistry. Note: Enrolment in CHEM1001 is not recommended for students who have already achieved an adequate performance in HSC Chemistry (or equivalent).CHEM1001 does not qualify as a prerequisite for any UNSW course, and students intending to progress to Level II Chemistry must subsequently complete, in sequence, CHEM1011/CHEM1021, or CHEM1031/1041. Students who complete CHEM1001 can count this course as a Level 1 course towards the total units of credit (UoC) for the Science component of their degree. Students who are currently enrolled in, or have already completed, any CHEM course, or MATS1101, or an equivalent course, are not eligible to enrol in CHEM1001.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"21c507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961997","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are continuously assessed by their demonstrator on their laboratory skills. Some of the skills are designated as "core", meaning that students need to have all of them as an essential requirement for passing the course. There are multiple opportunities across several weeks to get each "core" skill. Together, the "core" skills provide 10/20 in one lump sum. The remaining, "non-core" skills allow a student to gradually progress from 10/20 to 20/20. Students can view their skills portfolio in near-real-time by following a link in Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e5c507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e5c507a3db8a9410358b403c3a96199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"35c507a3db8a9410358b403c3a9619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

This is an invigilated test, held during one of the regular lecture slots in (approximately) week 4. The test consists of ~20 multi-choice questions. The test duration is 45 minutes. The course coordinator is available to provide one-on-one feedback, by appointment, after the test results are published on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"edc507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"edc507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961998","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"adc507a3db8a9410358b403c3a96199b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"60","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours' duration. It covers all aspects of the syllabus, including the theoretical aspects of the laboratory class. The exam consists of a mixture of multi-choice and written-answer questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e5c507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e5c507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e5c507a3db8a9410358b403c3a96199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"edc507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"edc507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"edc507a3db8a9410358b403c3a961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"adc507a3db8a9410358b403c3a96199f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Computer Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Most weeks during Term, there will be an online revision quiz for students to complete. The quizzes are accessed via Moodle. Each quiz consists of ~3 questions. Students need to get all answers correct in order to be awarded a mark of 1 for that quiz. Up to three attempts are allowed. At the end of Term, a student's best 6 out of 8 quiz marks will be added together, then scaled to a mark out of 10. These quizzes are open-book, and are designed to be primarily formative rather than summative.

Note: Enrolment in CHEM1001 is not recommended for students who have already achieved an adequate performance in HSC Chemistry (or equivalent).CHEM1001 does not qualify as a prerequisite for any UNSW course, and students intending to progress to Level II Chemistry must subsequently complete, in sequence, CHEM1011/CHEM1021, or CHEM1031/1041. Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy","description":"

This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to one year of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements. This knowledge is applied to understanding chemical bonding and intermolecular forces which together are responsible for determining the properties of materials. General principles of chemical equilibrium are developed and applied to chemical reactions involving acids and bases. The applications of the laws of Thermodynamics to chemical processes are described and ultimately linked to chemical equilibrium. The course includes an overview of chemical reactions involving electron transfer, including their applications in biology, corrosion and energy storage for portable electronic devices. 


Notes:


  1. Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 11 chemistry or CHEM1001.
  2. Students who complete CHEM1011 are unable to subsequently enrol in CHEM1001. However, students who have completed CHEM1001 will be permitted to proceed to enrol in CHEM1011.
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fce1ea78dbde9810358b403c3a9619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration, and covers the “mastery” topics only. The exam gives students the opportunity to earn merit grades. The questions are presented as problems written in paragraph style, and may draw together several different concepts.

\n

There is no requirement for any student to sit the final exam. Therefore, supplementary exams (excluding special consideration cases) will not be offered. Further, students will know before the exam whether or not they have passed the course. This will allow students to make informed choices about e.g. withdrawing from the course, or prioritising other courses during their exam preparation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"70e16e78dbde9810358b403c3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"70e16e78dbde9810358b403c3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"78e16e78dbde9810358b403c3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"78e16e78dbde9810358b403c3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f0e1ea78dbde9810358b403c3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"01e16e78dbde9810358b403c3a96193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work with individual practical reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory class already (in 2018) operates on a skills-assessment style, with students needing to earn “badges” that are awarded in real time by their demonstrator. The skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. No major changes are mooted for the laboratory assessment item in 2019.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"70e16e78dbde9810358b403c3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c9e16e78dbde9810358b403c3a961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are two in-session tests, one in each of weeks 4 and 8. The in-session tests will serve as a summative validation of students’ learning from the online platform. Prior to these tests, students will be required to engage in weekly online formative assessment and achieve 10/10 in each online quiz (unlimited attempts).

\n

The in-session tests are conducted under exam conditions. They contain 20 multi-choice questions, drawn from the same test bank as the weekly quizzes. The pass mark for each in-session test is 18/20. Students will have the opportunity to sit up to 3 “make-up tests” in subsequent weeks for equivalent credit, if they fail a test or miss it for any reason.

\n

Once a student has passed both in-session tests, they are awarded 40% of the total marks of the course. If a student does not pass both in-session tests, they are awarded 0% for this assessment item and are ineligible to pass the course.

contentlets.description:
This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to one year of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements. This knowledge is applied to understanding chemical bonding and intermolecular forces which together are responsible for determining the properties of materials. General principles of chemical equilibrium are developed and applied to chemical reactions involving acids and bases. The applications of the laws of Thermodynamics to chemical processes are described and ultimately linked to chemical equilibrium. The course includes an overview of chemical reactions involving electron transfer, including their applications in biology, corrosion and energy storage for portable electronic devices. 

Notes:

  1. Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 11 chemistry or CHEM1001.
  2. Students who complete CHEM1011 are unable to subsequently enrol in CHEM1001. However, students who have completed CHEM1001 will be permitted to proceed to enrol in CHEM1011.

Chemistry 1B: Elements, Compounds and Life","description":"

CHEM1021 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science. It enables students to develop further their knowledge of Chemistry and probes a diverse range of molecules and their reactions, focusing on applications such as drug development, functional materials, environmental chemistry, and renewable energies.


A key part of chemistry is to study the speed of chemical reactions providing a strong foundation for material covered later in the course.  The course introduces modern structure determination methods and the concepts of stereochemistry, which are important in understanding the shape and structure of chemicals.  The next section of the course provides an introduction to modern inorganic chemistry and use of the periodic table is a powerful predictive tool.  Important foci are the chemistries of main-group and transition metals.  Transition metal compounds, d-element electron configuration the reaction mechanisms exhibited by transition metal chemistry are discussed.  The final section of the course deals with the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds and provides an introduction to the field by emphasising the reaction mechanisms that provide insight into how reactions of these molecules proceed.  Students are introduced to a range of chemistry that enables the preparation of new molecules starting from readily available materials. The course concludes with a summary of how these concepts are applicable to the development of new pharmaceutical drugs.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"582f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619ba","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are two in-session tests, one in each of weeks 4 and 8. The in-session tests will serve as a summative validation of students’ learning from the online platform. Prior to these tests, students will be required to engage in weekly online formative assessment and achieve 10/10 in each online quiz (unlimited attempts).

\n

The in-session tests are conducted under exam conditions. They contain 20 multi-choice questions, drawn from the same test bank as the weekly quizzes. The pass mark for each in-session test is 18/20. Students will have the opportunity to sit up to 3 “make-up tests” in subsequent weeks for equivalent credit, if they fail a test or miss it for any reason.

\n

Once a student has passed both in-session tests, they are awarded 40% of the total marks of the course. If a student does not pass both in-session tests, they are awarded 0% for this assessment item and are ineligible to pass the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"082f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"402f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8c2f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c02f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c82f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"731f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a96196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration, and covers the “mastery” topics only. The exam gives students the opportunity to earn merit grades. The questions are presented as problems written in paragraph style, and may draw together several different concepts.

\n

There is no requirement for any student to sit the final exam. Therefore, supplementary exams (excluding special consideration cases) will not be offered. Further, students will know before the exam whether or not they have passed the course. This will allow students to make informed choices about e.g. withdrawing from the course, or prioritising other courses during their exam preparation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"082f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"402f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"4c2f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8c2f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c02f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c82f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb1f39abdb359850eb6b147a3a961972","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory class already (in 2018) operates on a skills-assessment style, with students needing to earn “badges” that are awarded in real time by their demonstrator. The skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. No major changes are mooted for the laboratory assessment item in 2019.

Higher Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy","description":"

This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 12 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements. This knowledge is applied to understanding chemical bonding and intermolecular forces which together are responsible for determining the properties of materials. General principles of chemical equilibrium are developed and applied to chemical reactions involving acids and bases. The applications of the laws of Thermodynamics to chemical processes are described and ultimately linked to chemical equilibrium. The course involves an overview of chemical reactions involving electron transfer, including their applications in biology, corrosion and energy storage for portable electronic devices.


This course covers the same material as CHEM1011, but has additional workshops that illuminate the role of chemistry in broader society, as well as the attributes of a professional chemistry researcher.


Note:


  1. Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 12 chemistry or CHEM1001.
  2. Students cannot subsequently enrol in CHEM1001 after completing CHEM1031. However, students may complete CHEM1001 followed by CHEM1031.
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f772aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619d7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are two in-session tests, one in each of weeks 4 and 8. The in-session tests will serve as a summative validation of students’ learning from the online platform. Prior to these tests, students will be required to engage in weekly online formative assessment and achieve 10/10 in each online quiz (unlimited attempts).

\n

The in-session tests are conducted under exam conditions. They contain 20 multi-choice questions, drawn from the same test bank as the weekly quizzes. The pass mark for each in-session test is 18/20. Students will have the opportunity to sit up to 3 “make-up tests” in subsequent weeks for equivalent credit, if they fail a test or miss it for any reason.

\n

Once a student has passed both in-session tests, they are awarded 40% of the total marks of the course. If a student does not pass both in-session tests, they are awarded 0% for this assessment item and are ineligible to pass the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f772aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f772aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f772aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ff72aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7b72aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration, and covers the “mastery” topics only. The exam gives students the opportunity to earn merit grades. The questions are presented as problems written in paragraph style, and may draw together several different concepts.

\n

There will be five questions in the exam. The lowest-scoring question will be automatically substituted by an assignment mark (if this leads to an overall mark increase). The assignment mark comes from continuous assessment of the "professional chemistry skills" workshops. This assessment includes a series of peer-marked oral presentations and written assignments, and an academic-marked reflective journal. 

\n

There is no requirement for any student to sit the final exam. Therefore, supplementary exams (excluding special consideration cases) will not be offered. Further, students will know before the exam whether or not they have passed the course. This will allow students to make informed choices about e.g. withdrawing from the course, or prioritising other courses during their exam preparation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f772aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f772aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f772aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"fb72aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ff72aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ff72aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c82aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619e6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory class already (in 2018) operates on a skills-assessment style, with students needing to earn “badges” that are awarded in real time by their demonstrator. The skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. No major changes are mooted for the laboratory assessment item in 2019.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ff72aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9082aeb8dbde9810358b403c3a9619fb","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM1031.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 12 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements. This knowledge is applied to understanding chemical bonding and intermolecular forces which together are responsible for determining the properties of materials. General principles of chemical equilibrium are developed and applied to chemical reactions involving acids and bases. The applications of the laws of Thermodynamics to chemical processes are described and ultimately linked to chemical equilibrium. The course involves an overview of chemical reactions involving electron transfer, including their applications in biology, corrosion and energy storage for portable electronic devices.

This course covers the same material as CHEM1011, but has additional workshops that illuminate the role of chemistry in broader society, as well as the attributes of a professional chemistry researcher.

Note:

  1. Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 12 chemistry or CHEM1001.
  2. Students cannot subsequently enrol in CHEM1001 after completing CHEM1031. However, students may complete CHEM1001 followed by CHEM1031.

Higher Chemistry 1B: Elements, Compounds and Life","description":"

CHEM1041 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science. It enables students to develop further their knowledge of Chemistry and probes a diverse range of molecules and their reactions, focusing on applications such as drug development, functional materials, environmental chemistry, and renewable energies.


A key part of chemistry is understanding the speed of chemical reactions, a concept that underpins much of the material that is taught later in the course. The course introduces modern structure determination methods and the concepts of stereochemistry, which are important in understanding the shape and structure of chemicals.  The next section of the course provides a thorough introduction to modern inorganic chemistry and use of the periodic table as a powerful predictive tool.  Important foci are the chemistries of main-group and transition metals.  Transition metal compounds, d-element electron configuration, new metal bonding theories and the key reaction mechanisms exhibited by transition metal chemistry are discussed.  The final section of the course deals with the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds and provides a thorough introduction to the field by emphasising the reaction mechanisms that provide insight into how reactions of these molecules proceed.  Students are introduced to a range of chemistry that enables the preparation of new molecules starting from readily available materials. The course concludes with a summary of how these concepts are applicable to the development of novel pharmaceutical drugs.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a322cb6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619a5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory class already (in 2018) operates on a skills-assessment style, with students needing to earn “badges” that are awarded in real time by their demonstrator. The skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. No major changes are mooted for the laboratory assessment item in 2019.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ab22cb6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"00320f6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration, and covers the “mastery” topics only. The exam gives students the opportunity to earn merit grades. The questions are presented as problems written in paragraph style, and may draw together several different concepts.

\n

There will be five questions in the exam. The lowest-scoring question will be automatically substituted by an assignment mark (if this leads to an overall mark increase). The assignment mark comes from continuous assessment of the "professional chemistry skills" workshops. This assessment includes a series of peer-marked oral presentations and written assignments, and an academic-marked reflective journal. 

\n

There is no requirement for any student to sit the final exam. Therefore, supplementary exams (excluding special consideration cases) will not be offered. Further, students will know before the exam whether or not they have passed the course. This will allow students to make informed choices about e.g. withdrawing from the course, or prioritising other courses during their exam preparation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"27220f6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"2f220f6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a322cb6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a322cb6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ab22cb6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab22cb6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af22cb6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b3220f6fdb4a9410358b403c3a9619c7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are two in-session tests, one in each of weeks 4 and 8. The in-session tests will serve as a summative validation of students’ learning from the online platform. Prior to these tests, students will be required to engage in weekly online formative assessment and achieve 10/10 in each online quiz (unlimited attempts).

\n

The in-session tests are conducted under exam conditions. They contain 20 multi-choice questions, drawn from the same test bank as the weekly quizzes. The pass mark for each in-session test is 18/20. Students will have the opportunity to sit up to 3 “make-up tests” in subsequent weeks for equivalent credit, if they fail a test or miss it for any reason.

\n

Once a student has passed both in-session tests, they are awarded 40% of the total marks of the course. If a student does not pass both in-session tests, they are awarded 0% for this assessment item and are ineligible to pass the course.

Higher Chemistry 1A (Medicinal): Atoms, Molecules and Energy","description":"

This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 12 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements. This knowledge is applied to understanding chemical bonding and intermolecular forces which together are responsible for determining the properties of materials. General principles of chemical equilibrium are developed and applied to chemical reactions involving acids and bases. The applications of the laws of Thermodynamics to chemical processes are described and ultimately linked to chemical equilibrium. The course concludes with an overview of chemical reactions involving electron transfer, including their applications in biology, corrosion and energy storage for portable electronic devices.


Students enrolled in CHEM1051 will attend the same lectures as CHEM1031, but will have unique tutorial and laboratory groups.


This course covers the same material as CHEM1011, but has additional workshops that illuminate the role of chemistry in broader society, as well as the attributes of a professional chemistry researcher.


Note:


  1. Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 12 chemistry or CHEM1001.
  2. Students may not enrol in CHEM1001 after completion of CHEM1051. However, students may complete CHEM1001 and proceed to enrol in CHEM1051.
  3. Enrolment in this course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry (3992) or Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry (Honours) (3999) or Bachelor of Law/Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry (4755).

The laboratory class already (in 2018) operates on a skills-assessment style, with students needing to earn “badges” that are awarded in real time by their demonstrator. The skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. No major changes are mooted for the laboratory assessment item in 2019.The laboratory class already (in 2018) operates on a skills-assessment style, with students needing to earn “badges” that are awarded in real time by their demonstrator. The skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. No major changes are mooted for the laboratory assessment item in 2019.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bcf2aaf8dbde9810358b403c3a9619dd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0df2eaf8dbde9810358b403c3a9619c4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are two in-session tests, one in each of weeks 4 and 8. The in-session tests will serve as a summative validation of students’ learning from the online platform. Prior to these tests, students will be required to engage in weekly online formative assessment and achieve 10/10 in each online quiz (unlimited attempts).

\n

The in-session tests are conducted under exam conditions. They contain 20 multi-choice questions, drawn from the same test bank as the weekly quizzes. The pass mark for each in-session test is 18/20. Students will have the opportunity to sit up to 3 “make-up tests” in subsequent weeks for equivalent credit, if they fail a test or miss it for any reason.

\n

Once a student has passed both in-session tests, they are awarded 40% of the total marks of the course. If a student does not pass both in-session tests, they are awarded 0% for this assessment item and are ineligible to pass the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"38f2eaf8dbde9810358b403c3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b4f2aaf8dbde9810358b403c3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b4f2aaf8dbde9810358b403c3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b4f2aaf8dbde9810358b403c3a9619df","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b4f2eaf8dbde9810358b403c3a961991","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration, and covers the “mastery” topics only. The exam gives students the opportunity to earn merit grades. The questions are presented as problems written in paragraph style, and may draw together several different concepts.

\n

There will be five questions in the exam. The lowest-scoring question will be automatically substituted by an assignment mark (if this leads to an overall mark increase). The assignment mark comes from continuous assessment of the "professional chemistry skills" workshops. This assessment includes a series of peer-marked oral presentations and written assignments, and an academic-marked reflective journal. 

\n

There is no requirement for any student to sit the final exam. Therefore, supplementary exams (excluding special consideration cases) will not be offered. Further, students will know before the exam whether or not they have passed the course. This will allow students to make informed choices about e.g. withdrawing from the course, or prioritising other courses during their exam preparation.

Higher Chemistry 1B (Medicinal): Elements, Compounds and Life","description":"

CHEM1061 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science. It enables students to develop further their knowledge of Chemistry and probes a diverse range of molecules and their reactions, focusing on applications such as drug development, functional materials, environmental chemistry, and renewable energies.


A key part of chemistry is understanding the speed of chemical reactions, a concept that underpins much of the material that is taught later in the course. The course introduces modern structure determination methods and the concepts of stereochemistry, which are important in understanding the shape and structure of chemicals.  The next section of the course provides a thorough introduction to modern inorganic chemistry and use of the periodic table as a powerful predictive tool.  Important foci are the chemistries of main-group and transition metals.  Transition metal compounds, d-element electron configuration, new metal bonding theories and the key reaction mechanisms exhibited by transition metal chemistry are discussed.  The final section of the course deals with the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds and provides a thorough introduction to the field by emphasising the reaction mechanisms that provide insight into how reactions of these molecules proceed.  Students are introduced to a range of chemistry that enables the preparation of new molecules starting from readily available materials. The course concludes with a summary of how these concepts are applicable to the chemistry of amino acids, peptides and proteins.


The lecture material is the same as for CHEM1041, but there are specific tutorial and lab classes for CHEM1061.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3d221763db35d850eb6b147a3a96195d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration, and covers the “mastery” topics only. The exam gives students the opportunity to earn merit grades. The questions are presented as problems written in paragraph style, and may draw together several different concepts.

\n

A student's worst exam question will be automatically substituted by an assignment mark (if this leads to an overall mark increase). The assignment mark comes from continuous assessment of the "professional chemistry skills" workshops. This assessment includes a series of peer-marked oral presentations and written assignments.

\n

There is no requirement for any student to sit the final exam. Therefore, supplementary exams (excluding special consideration cases) will not be offered. Further, students will know before the exam whether or not they have passed the course. This will allow students to make informed choices about e.g. withdrawing from the course, or prioritising other courses during their exam preparation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"25221763db35d850eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"31221763db35d850eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6d221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a9221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e1221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e5221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"11221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

There are two in-session tests, one in each of weeks 4 and 8. The in-session tests will serve as a summative validation of students’ learning from the online platform. Prior to these tests, students will be required to engage in weekly online formative assessment and achieve 10/10 in each online quiz (unlimited attempts).

\n

The in-session tests are conducted under exam conditions. They contain 20 multi-choice questions, drawn from the same test bank as the weekly quizzes. The pass mark for each in-session test is 18/20. Students will have the opportunity to sit up to 3 “make-up tests” in subsequent weeks for equivalent credit, if they fail a test or miss it for any reason.

\n

Once a student has passed both in-session tests, they are awarded 40% of the total marks of the course. If a student does not pass both in-session tests, they are awarded 0% for this assessment item and are ineligible to pass the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"25221763db35d850eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6d221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a9221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e5221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59221763db35d850eb6b147a3a961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory class already (in 2018) operates on a skills-assessment style, with students needing to earn “badges” that are awarded in real time by their demonstrator. The skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. No major changes are mooted for the laboratory assessment item in 2019.

This course will provide students with an understanding of what medicinal chemistry is and how it is carried out. It will describe the interdisciplinary process of how pharmaceutical drugs are designed and developed. 


The course is based on a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops and colloquia given by academic staff from the Faculties of Science and Medicine plus visiting specialists, on topics of relevance to medicinal chemistry.  Students will have the opportunity to visit some of the biomedical facilities located on the UNSW campus.


The course is only available to students enrolled in program 3992, 3999 and 4755 and cannot be used as a general education course.


Note: Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 12 chemistry.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3437a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961979","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research project seminars","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

You and your partner will deliver a 5-minute PowerPoint presentation to the class, during the regular timetabled workshop in weeks 3, 6 and 9.

For each presentation, you should ensure that both members of the pair have equal speaking time. You will be marked individually, by the academic staff members in attendance.

You will have a different partner for each workshop presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3037a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7c37a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b837a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2037a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961949","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

The mid-session test is tentatively scheduled to take place during one of your regular lecture times in Week 5. But this is subject to change, depending e.g. on room availability. See Moodle for the definitive information on times and venues.

The mid-session test consists of a mixture of multi-choice and written-answer questions. You will enter your answers directly into the test booklet.

The test is conducted under exam conditions (see the UNSW assessment policy below for further information). In particular, you must write your names and ID on your test paper before the end of writing time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3037a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7c37a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b837a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6837a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research project reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You and your partner will submit a 2-to-3-page written report at the end weeks 3, 6 and 9.

For each report, you and your partner will receive the same mark.

You will have a different partner for each report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3037a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7c37a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b837a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ac37a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration. It consists of a mixture of multi-choice and written-answer questions.

contentlets.description:
This course will provide students with an understanding of what medicinal chemistry is and how it is carried out. It will describe the interdisciplinary process of how pharmaceutical drugs are designed and developed. 

The course is based on a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops and colloquia given by academic staff from the Faculties of Science and Medicine plus visiting specialists, on topics of relevance to medicinal chemistry.  Students will have the opportunity to visit some of the biomedical facilities located on the UNSW campus.

The course is only available to students enrolled in program 3992, 3999 and 4755 and cannot be used as a general education course.

Note: Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 12 chemistry.
contentlets.title: Introductory Medicinal Chemistry

Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy (Terminating)","description":"

Enrolment to this online course is restricted to students who have sought and been granted approval from the School of Chemistry. It is aimed as an alternative to CHEM1011 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to the exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic.


This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to one year of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements. This knowledge is applied to understanding chemical bonding and intermolecular forces which together are responsible for determining the properties of materials. General principles of chemical equilibrium are developed and applied to chemical reactions involving acids and bases. The applications of the laws of Thermodynamics to chemical processes are described and ultimately linked to chemical equilibrium. The course includes an overview of chemical reactions involving electron transfer, including their applications in biology, corrosion and energy storage for portable electronic devices. 


Notes:


  1. Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 11 chemistry or CHEM1001.
  2. Students who complete CHEM1511 are unable to subsequently enrol in CHEM1001. However, students who have completed CHEM1001 will be permitted to proceed to enrol in CHEM1511.
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3ff99c15dbf4fc50fe4b322af4961927","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration, and covers the “mastery” topics only. The exam gives students the opportunity to earn merit grades. The questions are presented as problems written in paragraph style, and may draw together several different concepts.

There is no requirement for any student to sit the final exam. Therefore, supplementary exams (excluding special consideration cases) will not be offered. Further, students will know before the exam whether or not they have passed the course. This will allow students to make informed choices about e.g. withdrawing from the course, or prioritising other courses during their exam preparation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f3a1055dbf4fc50fe4b322af4961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"375a1055dbf4fc50fe4b322af496199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"626a9455dbf4fc50fe4b322af4961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ccea9855dbf4fc50fe4b322af49619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fc5a1055dbf4fc50fe4b322af49619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"01bbdc95dbf4fc50fe4b322af496190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are two in-session tests, one in each of weeks 4 and 8. The in-session tests will serve as a summative validation of students’ learning from the online platform. Prior to these tests, students will be required to engage in weekly online formative assessment and achieve 10/10 in each online quiz (unlimited attempts).

The in-session tests are conducted under exam conditions. They contain 20 multi-choice questions, drawn from the same test bank as the weekly quizzes. The pass mark for each in-session test is 18/20. Students will have the opportunity to sit up to 3 “make-up tests” in subsequent weeks for equivalent credit, if they fail a test or miss it for any reason.

Once a student has passed both in-session tests, they are awarded 40% of the total marks of the course. If a student does not pass both in-session tests, they are awarded 0% for this assessment item and are ineligible to pass the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f3a1055dbf4fc50fe4b322af4961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"375a1055dbf4fc50fe4b322af496199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"626a9455dbf4fc50fe4b322af4961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fc5a1055dbf4fc50fe4b322af49619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2b2b1495dbf4fc50fe4b322af49619a1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Online laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Laboratory skills are divided into “core skills” (10%, hurdle) and “non-core skills” (10%, graded), by analogy with the proposed “threshold” / “mastery” split of the theory content. Delivery of this material in an online mode includes recorded material coupled to purpose-built exercises aimed at delivering the pedagogic outcomes of laboratory work as effectively as possible. Students are required  to attend an online class that is staffed in order to provide direct feedback. In order to obtain a mark for each class, the students must complete a Moodle quiz before leaving - the aim of the quiz is to ensure that the key learning outcomes of the class have been achieved.

(Terminating) ","description":"

Enrolment to this online course is restricted to students who have sought and been granted approval from the School of Chemistry. It is aimed as an alternative to CHEM1021 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to the exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic.


CHEM1521 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science. It enables students to develop further their knowledge of Chemistry and probes a diverse range of molecules and their reactions, focusing on applications such as drug development, functional materials, environmental chemistry, and renewable energies.


A key part of chemistry is to study the speed of chemical reactions providing a strong foundation for material covered later in the course.  The course introduces modern structure determination methods and the concepts of stereochemistry, which are important in understanding the shape and structure of chemicals.  The next section of the course provides an introduction to modern inorganic chemistry and use of the periodic table is a powerful predictive tool.  Important foci are the chemistries of main-group and transition metals.  Transition metal compounds, d-element electron configuration the reaction mechanisms exhibited by transition metal chemistry are discussed.  The final section of the course deals with the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds and provides an introduction to the field by emphasising the reaction mechanisms that provide insight into how reactions of these molecules proceed.  Students are introduced to a range of chemistry that enables the preparation of new molecules starting from readily available materials. The course concludes with a summary of how these concepts are applicable to the development of new pharmaceutical drugs.

Assessment in the laboratory is done on a “skills” basis. A student must demonstrate that they have acquired all of the “core skills” in order to be eligible to pass the course. The “core skills” will give 10/20 in one lump sum; the remaining “non-core (graded) skills” will take the mark from 10/20 up to 20/20 for the online laboratory component of the course.

The lab assessment runs through the term and covers a broad range of the course content.

Attendance of at least 80% of the scheduled online laboratory classes in the term in order to be eligible to pass the course.

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration. It will consist of multi-choice and written-answer questions. A minimum mark of 35% in the final exam is an essential requirement for passing the course. This is in addition to the requirement for obtaining 50% overall.

The mid-session test is tentatively scheduled to take place during week 5. The test is conducted under exam conditions. It is of 45 minutes’ duration and contains ~15 multi-choice questions, covering the topics of kinetics; isomerism & stereochemistry; and structure determination.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c6244018db103c90fe4b322af4961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c6244018db103c90fe4b322af496192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce244018db103c90fe4b322af496192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ce244018db103c90fe4b322af496192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"52248018db103c90fe4b322af4961954","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Weekly revision quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The online quizzes must be completed most weeks during the term. These are primarily designed to be a learning feedback tool not an assessment process: they ensure consistent learning. Each quiz consists of ~5 questions.

The weekly quizzes address small aspects of the course - the body whole of the quizzes cover the whole course content.

contentlets.description:
Enrolment to this online course is restricted to students who have sought and been granted approval from the School of Chemistry. It is aimed as an alternative to CHEM1021 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to the exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic.

CHEM1521 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science. It enables students to develop further their knowledge of Chemistry and probes a diverse range of molecules and their reactions, focusing on applications such as drug development, functional materials, environmental chemistry, and renewable energies.

A key part of chemistry is to study the speed of chemical reactions providing a strong foundation for material covered later in the course.  The course introduces modern structure determination methods and the concepts of stereochemistry, which are important in understanding the shape and structure of chemicals.  The next section of the course provides an introduction to modern inorganic chemistry and use of the periodic table is a powerful predictive tool.  Important foci are the chemistries of main-group and transition metals.  Transition metal compounds, d-element electron configuration the reaction mechanisms exhibited by transition metal chemistry are discussed.  The final section of the course deals with the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds and provides an introduction to the field by emphasising the reaction mechanisms that provide insight into how reactions of these molecules proceed.  Students are introduced to a range of chemistry that enables the preparation of new molecules starting from readily available materials. The course concludes with a summary of how these concepts are applicable to the development of new pharmaceutical drugs.
contentlets.title: Chemistry 1B: Elements, Compounds and Life (Terminating)

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM1777 - Chemistry of Cosmetics and Personal Care Products","description":"

This course will explain how cosmetics and personal care products work from a scientific standpoint. Chemistry plays a key role in the manufacturing and continual improvement of personal care and other household products. It is involved in all stages, from chemical extraction of natural products to the packaging of final consumer products. Throughout the course, students will learn the interaction of skin-care chemicals with lipids in the skin, the suspension of oil in emulsions, how foundation products scatter light to hide skin blemishes, and how sunscreens filter or scatter UV light. Furthermore, the students will learn how to interpret ingredient lists and understand their role. 


Marketing hype and trends, such as anti-aging, will be dissected to examine the underlying scientific principles and negative campaigns analysed to evaluate their veracity. Additionally, we intend the course to have a practical component, where students will learn to make their own cosmetics and household products (soaps and sanitisers) in a chemistry laboratory and understand some of the techniques used in the personal care products industry to assess products prior to taking them to market.

contentlets.description:
This course will explain how cosmetics and personal care products work from a scientific standpoint. Chemistry plays a key role in the manufacturing and continual improvement of personal care and other household products. It is involved in all stages, from chemical extraction of natural products to the packaging of final consumer products. Throughout the course, students will learn the interaction of skin-care chemicals with lipids in the skin, the suspension of oil in emulsions, how foundation products scatter light to hide skin blemishes, and how sunscreens filter or scatter UV light. Furthermore, the students will learn how to interpret ingredient lists and understand their role. 

Marketing hype and trends, such as anti-aging, will be dissected to examine the underlying scientific principles and negative campaigns analysed to evaluate their veracity. Additionally, we intend the course to have a practical component, where students will learn to make their own cosmetics and household products (soaps and sanitisers) in a chemistry laboratory and understand some of the techniques used in the personal care products industry to assess products prior to taking them to market.

Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/CHEM1011","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"CHEM1011","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CHEM1811 - Engineering Chemistry 1A","description":"

This course builds on an introductory knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 and 12 chemistry) to explore the engineering aspects of chemistry. The course builds from the quantum mechanical structure of atoms and leads to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements. This knowledge is applied to understanding chemical bonding and intermolecular forces which together are responsible for determining the properties of materials. General principles of chemical equilibrium are developed and applied to chemical reactions involving acids and bases. The practical aspects of the flow of material and energy within a process are extended into applications of the laws of thermodynamics to chemical processes and ultimately linked to chemical equilibrium. The course concludes with an overview of chemical reactions involving electron transfer, including their applications in biology, corrosion and energy storage for portable electronic devices.


Note: Assumed knowledge equivalent to year 12 chemistry or CHEM1001.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"30d65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"\"Threshold\" tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The syllabus is divided into "threshold" and "mastery" topics (50:50). The "threshold" topics will be continuously assessed throughout semester, using a series of multi-choice tests with a high pass mark (e.g. 90%). Students will need to pass ALL of the threshold tests in order to be eligible to pass the course. Students will be given multiple opportunities to pass each test (or a variant thereof) if necessary. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"20d65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7cd65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b8d65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f4d65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"10d65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory class will be assessed using an innovative "skills-based" assessment model, which was piloted in CHEM1011 / CHEM1021 / CHEM1031 / CHEM1041 in 2015-16. Under this new model, students are assessed in real time by their demonstrators, who observe their laboratory skills in real time and mark off a series of "check-boxes" using an iPad-based interface. Similar to the "threshold" / "mastery" style of lecture assessment, the laboratory assessment is divided into "core" and "mastery" skills (50%) each, with students needing to attain all of the "core" skills (and being given multiple opportunities to do so if necessary).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"34d65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"58d65d3fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The syllabus is divided into "threshold" and "mastery" topics (50:50). The assessment structure of the course will mean that students can pass on the strength of their "threshold" knowledge alone (see below). Accordingly, when students attend the final exam they will know that they have already passed the course. The exam will cover "mastery" topics only, and it will be designed to be very tough (so that, for example, a bare-pass-level student will not score much above zero in the exam).

Engineering Chemistry 1B","description":"

This course further develops the introduction to the engineering aspects of chemistry started in CHEM1811. The course explores organic and inorganic chemistry through the investigation of topics such as kinetics, control of reactions, structure determination, stereochemistry, main group chemistry, transition metal chemistry, and the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds. There will be an emphasis on the engineering applications of chemistry in drug development, functional materials, environmental chemistry, and renewable energies. The laboratory component aims to instil an appreciation of safe working practices in a chemistry laboratory and laboratory skills widely used in chemical engineering and chemistry related laboratories.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d21c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961977","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The assessment structure of the course will mean that students can pass on the strength of their "threshold" knowledge alone (see above). Accordingly, when students attend the final exam they will know that they have already passed the course. The exam will cover "mastery" topics only, and it will be designed to be very tough (so that, for example, a bare-pass-level student will not score much above zero in the exam).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1e1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5a1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"961c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d21c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory class will be assessed using an innovative "skills-based" assessment model, which was piloted in CHEM1011 / CHEM1021 / CHEM1031 / CHEM1041 in 2015-16. Under this new model, students are assessed in real time by their demonstrators, who observe their laboratory skills in real time and mark off a series of "check-boxes" using an iPad-based interface. Similar to the "threshold" / "mastery" style of lecture assessment, the laboratory assessment is divided into "core" and "mastery" skills (50%) each, with students needing to attain all of the "core" skills (and being given multiple opportunities to do so if necessary).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d61c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"461c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"\"Threshold\" tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The syllabus is divided into "threshold" and "mastery" topics (50:50). The "threshold" topics will be continuously assessed throughout semester, using a series of multi-choice tests with a high pass mark (e.g. 90%). Students will need to pass ALL of the threshold tests in order to be eligible to pass the course. Students will be given multiple opportunities to pass each test (or a variant thereof) if necessary.

CHEM1829 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science. It enables students to develop further their knowledge of Biological Chemistry and probes a diverse range of synthetic and biological molecules including enzymes and their reactions, focusing on applications such as drug development, bioenergetics and metabolism.


A key part of biological chemistry is to study the speed of chemical reactions providing a strong foundation for material covered later in the course. The course introduces modern structure determination methods and the concepts of stereochemistry, which are important in understanding the shape and structure of chemicals. The next section of the course provides an introduction to transition metals chemistry. Transition metal compounds, d-element electron configuration, new metal bonding theories, transition metals and colours and the key reaction mechanisms exhibited by transition metal chemistry are discussed. The next section of the course deals with the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds and their reactions. Students are introduced to a range of chemistry that enables their preparation of new molecules starting from readily available materials. The course then gives a summary of how these concepts are applicable to the chemistry of amino acids, proteins, carbohydrates, nucleic acids and lipids. The final section of this course introduces students to the field of Biological organic chemistry, including enzymology, bioenergetics, carbohydrate metabolism, oxidative phosphorylation, metabolism and hormone function. 


Note: Restricted to programs 3181, 3182 and 3952, and students doing a Vision Science major.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"972fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619c5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The final exam is of 2 hours’ duration. The exam covers the entire syllabus of the course. The chemistry component (36.67%) consists of a mixture of multi-choice and written-answer questions. The biochemistry component (23.33%) consists of multi-choice questions only.

Your examination result will not be communicated to you explicitly; instead, you will learn your overall mark for the course in the usual manner. If you wish to see your detailed examination results, contact the Course Coordinator once your mark has been released.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4b2fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4f2fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9b2fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"322fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619a1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly computer assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"6.67","description":"

There will be an online quiz for you to attempt, most weeks during the Term. These quizzes are open-book, and you may use as much help (e.g. peer support) as you need. You may make a maximum of three attempts at each quiz. You must get all answers correct on one of your attempts in order to be awarded a mark of 1 for a particular quiz. At the end of the term, your best 5 quiz marks will be added together then scaled to give a mark out of 6.67.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4f2fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a2fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619a5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory work","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"23.33","description":"

The laboratory class is continuously assessed. Since this component of the course involves a wide variety of experiments performed in both the chemistry and BABS laboratories, the format of continuous assessment neccessarily varies throughout the term. Assessable activities within the laboratory class will include: demonstration of skills acquisition; report writing; and a quiz.

CHEMISTRY PORTION (13.33%)

The definitive source of information about laboratory assessment is the Laboratory Manual (available on Moodle). A few key points are repeated here:

  • Assessment in the chemistry portion of the laboratory is done on a “skills” basis. In particular, you must demonstrate that you’ve acquired all of the “core skills” in order to be eligible to pass the course. 
  • If you fail to earn any core skills during the regular lab weeks, you should attend a make-up lab to get a last chance to be awarded your missing core skills.
  • All experiments require pre-lab work to be completed before your lab class.
  • You must attend the laboratory class shown on your official timetable. If you arrive more than 20 minutes late to a laboratory class you will be refused entry and marked absent.
  • Safety eyewear, a laboratory coat and fully enclosed footwear must be worn in the laboratory. You will not be permitted to work in thongs or open-top shoes or sandals or without a laboratory coat and safety eyewear.
  • Repeat students must apply to the first year laboratory coordinator if they want exemption from laboratory classes. Exemption is not automatic and is decided on a case-by-case basis.

BIOCHEMISTRY PORTION (10%)

The biochemistry portion of the laboratory class is assessed on two occasions. The first occasion is a report to be submitted based on the glycolysis lab (3.33%). The second occasion is a quiz which is conducted within the laboratory class (6.67%). Full details are on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"032fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4b2fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"872fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c32fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b22fb9abdb359850eb6b147a3a9619aa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

The mid-session test is tentatively scheduled to take place during one of your regular lecture times in Week 5. But this is subject to change, depending e.g. on room availability. See Moodle for the definitive information on times and venues.

The mid-session test consists of ~20 multi-choice questions. You will enter your answers on a generalised answer sheet.

The test is conducted under exam conditions (see the UNSW assessment policy below for further information). In particular, you must remember to write your names and ID on both your test paper and the generalised answer sheet before the end of writing time.

contentlets.description:
CHEM1829 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science. It enables students to develop further their knowledge of Biological Chemistry and probes a diverse range of synthetic and biological molecules including enzymes and their reactions, focusing on applications such as drug development, bioenergetics and metabolism.

A key part of biological chemistry is to study the speed of chemical reactions providing a strong foundation for material covered later in the course. The course introduces modern structure determination methods and the concepts of stereochemistry, which are important in understanding the shape and structure of chemicals. The next section of the course provides an introduction to transition metals chemistry. Transition metal compounds, d-element electron configuration, new metal bonding theories, transition metals and colours and the key reaction mechanisms exhibited by transition metal chemistry are discussed. The next section of the course deals with the chemistry of carbon-containing compounds and their reactions. Students are introduced to a range of chemistry that enables their preparation of new molecules starting from readily available materials. The course then gives a summary of how these concepts are applicable to the chemistry of amino acids, proteins, carbohydrates, nucleic acids and lipids. The final section of this course introduces students to the field of Biological organic chemistry, including enzymology, bioenergetics, carbohydrate metabolism, oxidative phosphorylation, metabolism and hormone function. 

Note: Restricted to programs 3181, 3182 and 3952, and students doing a Vision Science major.
contentlets.title: Biological Chemistry for Optometry Students

contentlets.description: Designed for students in the Exercise Physiology program, this course covers the chemistry required to understand atomic and molecular structure, states of matter, thermodynamics, equilibrium chemistry in aqueous solution and introductory kinetics, the chemistry of organic compounds, stereochemistry, functional groups and their reactions especially amines, amides, acids and esters, redox chemistry of oxygen. Case studies and experiments relevant to health and exercise science are also included. The Chemistry in the course will prepare students for the Level II Biochemistry and Anatomy components of their programs. Assumed knowledge: A basic knowledge of Chemistry equivalent to the NSW Year 11 Chemistry syllabus. It is also recommended that BABS1201 be taken concurrently. Note: Students who have completed this course and wish to take further Chemistry courses should consult the School of Chemistry or their Program Advisor. This course is designed to cover a highly specific area of Chemistry and will not be useful for any students who wish to further their Chemistry knowledge.
contentlets.title: Chemistry for Exercise Physiology
