","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM2011","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM2011 - Physical Chemistry: Molecules, Energy and Change","description":"

Physical Chemistry seeks to explain chemical processes in terms of energy changes and the molecular nature of matter. This course introduces quantum mechanics and its role in determining the energy levels of atoms and molecules, followed by the physical basis for understanding the factors affecting reaction rates, the role of reaction mechanisms, and molecular theory of reaction rates. The course then introduces the molecular basis underpinning the laws of thermodynamics and their applications in chemistry, with specific attention given to the application of thermodynamics to electrochemical processes. To complete, the course introduces the surface and colloid chemistry which explains many important natural and technologically important phenomena.

Organic molecules are at the heart of the chemistry of life and industry. This course builds on the fundamental chemical principles learned in first year, exploring many of the central reactions that form the basis of living processes, modern research, and contemporary industrial transformations.  The course contains a problem-based module on the application of spectroscopic methods to organic structure elucidation, focusing on infrared and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Several modules then develop knowledge of major classes of organic reactions (including compounds containing alkenes, alkynes, aromatic rings, and carbonyl groups) by enriching a study of key reactions with an understanding of relevant reaction mechanisms. The concepts of reactivity and selectivity in the manipulation of more complex compounds will be highlighted, with an emphasis on biologically relevant molecules. Interleaved throughout the course will be relevant examples from contemporary chemical industries, and important medicinal and pharmaceutical examples.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c68549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a96193e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"44","description":"

The actual weighting of this assessment is 44%. The exam covers all of the syllabus material EXCEPT the first 9 lectures, which are already covered by the mid-session examination. The exam is a combination of multi-choice and written-answer questions. It is a closed book exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7d8549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b98549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f58549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d8549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"17","description":"

The actual weighting of this assessment is 17%. It focuses only on the first 9 lectures. The test comprises a combination of multi-choice and written answer questions. The marks are returned to students via Moodle, and the lecturer is also available to give one-on-one feedback by appointment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7d8549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b98549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"658549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory practical component","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

There is a laboratory class every week for nine weeks during term, and this part of the course is continuously assessed. Students are assessed using new mode of "skills-based" assessment in the laboratory class, in addition to their experimental results and writeups.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d8549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"9","description":"

There are three take-home assignments, with deadlines throughout semester, equalling 9% in total. These are primarily designed to be a formative assessment. The assignments are returned to students, annotated by the marker, in order to provide feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7d8549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b98549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f58549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a58549ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM2021.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Inorganic Chemistry: The Elements","description":"

This course provides a general introduction to both theoretical and practical aspects of advanced inorganic chemistry. The principles of quantum theory and symmetry are explained and then explored to account for the electronic and geometric structure of atoms and molecules. These concepts are then expanded further to include the study of such diverse areas as transition metals, organometallic chemistry and bioinorganic chemistry. The relevance of much of this chemistry to the world around us is highlighted with real examples of inorganic chemistry in action. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e6d30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"9","description":"

There are three take-home assignments, one for each of the first three sections. The assignments are returned to the students to provide feedback (annotated marked script).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a6d30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aed30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aed30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ad30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The exam covers material from the 2nd and 3rd lecturers material.

\n

The exam contains written-answer questions. The breakdown of the exam components is 50:50 for Section 2 and Section 3.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aed30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aed30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ad30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Course","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

There is a laboratory class that runs throughout the entire teaching period.

\n

This aspect of the course is continuously assessed by "prelab" questions, the keeping of lab book records and a series of individual lab reports.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a2d30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a6d30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aed30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aed30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"32d30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619d2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Mid-term exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"21","description":"

The mid-term exam will cover just the material in Section A (1st lecturer). The exam will be held after the students have feedback from the assignment from Section A.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a6d30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619c2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"62d30c33dbbf6850fe4b322af49619cc","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM2031.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM2041","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM2041 - Analytical Chemistry: Essential Methods","description":"

This course teaches the essential methods in analytical chemistry applicable to chemists, biologists, and most other disciplines of science. The course covers methods for treating analytical data including estimation of uncertainties, chromatography and other separation techniques, the applications of spectroscopy (UV/Visible absorption, infrared, fluorescence, NMR and mass spectrometry) to analysis and electrochemistry including pH measurements. These analytical techniques will be applied to solving chemical structure problems and interesting applications of these techniques will be covered (e.g., gene and protein sequencing and metal speciation in environmental samples).

Enrolment to this online course is restricted to students who have sought and been granted approval from the School of Chemistry. It is aimed as an alternative to 2021 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to the exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic.


Organic molecules are at the heart of the chemistry of life and industry. This course builds on the fundamental chemical principles learned in first year, exploring many of the central reactions that form the basis of living processes, modern research, and contemporary industrial transformations.  The course contains a problem-based module on the application of spectroscopic methods to organic structure elucidation, focusing on infrared and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Several modules then develop knowledge of major classes of organic reactions (including compounds containing alkenes, alkynes, aromatic rings, and carbonyl groups) by enriching a study of key reactions with an understanding of relevant reaction mechanisms. The concepts of reactivity and selectivity in the manipulation of more complex compounds will be highlighted, with an emphasis on biologically relevant molecules. Interleaved throughout the course will be relevant examples from contemporary chemical industries, and important medicinal and pharmaceutical examples.

(Terminating)","description":"

Enrolment to this online course is restricted to students who have sought and been granted approval from the School of Chemistry. It is aimed as an alternative to CHEM2031 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to the exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic.


This course provides a general introduction to both theoretical and practical aspects of advanced inorganic chemistry. The principles of quantum theory and symmetry are explained and then explored to account for the electronic and geometric structure of atoms and molecules. These concepts are then expanded further to include the study of such diverse areas as transition metals, organometallic chemistry and bioinorganic chemistry. The relevance of much of this chemistry to the world around us is highlighted with real examples of inorganic chemistry in action.

(Terminating)","description":"

Enrolment to this online course is restricted to students who have sought and been granted approval from the School of Chemistry. It is aimed as an alternative to 2041 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic. The lectures and online exams will be in common with 2041, but online labs will replace the face-to-face component of 2041.


This course teaches the essential methods in analytical chemistry applicable to chemists, biologists, and most other disciplines of science. The course covers methods for treating analytical data including estimation of uncertainties, chromatography and other separation techniques, the applications of spectroscopy (UV/Visible absorption, infrared, fluorescence, NMR and mass spectrometry) to analysis and electrochemistry including pH measurements. These analytical techniques will be applied to solving chemical structure problems and interesting applications of these techniques will be covered (e.g., gene and protein sequencing and metal speciation in environmental samples).

contentlets.description:
Enrolment to this online course is restricted to students who have sought and been granted approval from the School of Chemistry. It is aimed as an alternative to 2041 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic. The lectures and online exams will be in common with 2041, but online labs will replace the face-to-face component of 2041.

This course teaches the essential methods in analytical chemistry applicable to chemists, biologists, and most other disciplines of science. The course covers methods for treating analytical data including estimation of uncertainties, chromatography and other separation techniques, the applications of spectroscopy (UV/Visible absorption, infrared, fluorescence, NMR and mass spectrometry) to analysis and electrochemistry including pH measurements. These analytical techniques will be applied to solving chemical structure problems and interesting applications of these techniques will be covered (e.g., gene and protein sequencing and metal speciation in environmental samples).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"39af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4aaf9df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bdaf5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

There will be 8 lab experiments, one run each week, from weeks 1-10.  All 8 labs will require attendence and written reports to be submitted one week after the lab report is complete.  All laboratory reports will carry the same weight towards the lab compinent.  Assessment on the lab reports will be provided by demonstrators 1 week after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"39af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3daf9df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4aaf9df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f9af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"65af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam will be comprehensive, and will be given during exam session.  It will cover questions from all 4 topics taught during the lecture.  Marked exams will be available for students to view, if they request it, after grade submissions. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"39af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3daf9df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4aaf9df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bdaf5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f9af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"adaf5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Assessment 1 will be performed after the first two topics are taught (water, spectroscopy; amino acids and proteins).  2 weeks after this in term test, grades and marked papers will be given back to students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3daf9df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f9af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e5af5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM2921.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course covers the chemical structures and properties of protein, carbohydrate, lipids, minerals, and vitamins, and their functions in food systems. It also covers the principles of chemical and instrumental techniques for the qualitative and quantitative analysis of food composition. The laboratory sessions focus on analysis of major and minor food nutrients, and data interpretation.
contentlets.title: Food Chemistry

honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM2996","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM2996 - Introduction to Chemistry Research","description":"

This course provides an essential introduction for students undertaking research in the School of Chemistry. The course results in a written research proposal that will provide an account of relevant scientific literature and a description of the research work has been undertaken during the program. Students will also present a short seminar based on their work. Other required research training, including relevant instruction on topics including literature search referencing in scientific articles, and maintaining accurate notes on the scientific work completed.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2aedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

The students will each present 3 slides (intro, research results and conclusion) of their project that they completed during the 6 weeks in a research lab. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"deedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0eedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation on group structure","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The students will study several research groups and provide their assessment of how a research group is organised including management, ordering chemicals/supplies, how papers are written, authors are organise on papers, equipment is fixed etc.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1eedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"deedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"42edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"30","description":"

The students will write a 6 page (double spaced) report on their research project.  The report will include similar information as the students presentation, but will be in a written format. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1aedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"56edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"92edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"deedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"46edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961964","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature and abstract writing","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will also need to demonstrate competence in searching the literature to identify specific articles.  They will be required to write an abstract on a specific article and show they understand how to use endnotes to include references.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1eedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"56edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"92edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"deedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8aedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research diary and notebook","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The research diary and notebook will document the weekly progress of the student in the lab and will provide information on how effectively they progressed on this project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1aedb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"56edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"92edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c2edb8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM2996.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM2999","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM2999 - Special Project in Chemistry","description":"

This course provides an early introduction to the university research environment through undertaking an authentic short research project under the direction of a Chemistry academic member of staff taking advantage of UNSW's world-class researchers and research facilities. Student engage directly with academics and their research group, becoming involved with the group's regular activities such as group meetings, while learning important research and transferable graduate skills prized throughout academia, industry and business.



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5702c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students must write a report aimed at the scientifically literate general public. It must contain Abstract, Literature Review and/or Introduction, Project Aims, Methodology, Results, Discussion, Conclusions, References.

The report wil be completed in Week 11 and must satisfactorily address all the below points. Students will be provided feedback by three markers including their supervisor and one person external to the topic area. For any areas which are judged unsatisfactory, students will be given one opportunity to prepare an improved report (to be submitted by the end of the exam period), otherwise an unsatisfactory grade will be awarded.

This points are:

·      Did the abstract adequately summarise the project describing the accomplishments and significance?

·      Did the introduction (literature review) detail the literature and explain the rationale for the project?

·      Did the research project explain what the goal was, and then what was accomplished?

·      Are the techniques/methodology used in the project described and justified?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0302c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8702c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c302c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3202c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Summary Document","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Definition:

Research Activity: Task performed by the student that produces original material or data to contribute to the project objectives.  This original material or data may include chemicals, computer programs, spectra, interview transcripts, calculation results, questions, analysis, collation and more.

Research Work: Task performed by the student in order to fulfil the project objectives. This includes both research activities as defined above and those tasks required to prepare for research activities, for example, literature review, learning new synthetic, instrumental or computational technique and learning new scientific content knowledge.

Assessment Task:

Summary of Research Work and Activity often in spreadsheet form, which must include identification of Date, Activity, Research Skills demonstrated/ acquired and Transferable Skills/ Graduate Attributes demonstrated/ acquired.

Grading comments:

To be awarded as satisfactory, the summary document must contain evidence that the student has:

  • learnt new research skills during the project
  • identified relevant transferable skills that you have developed and/or strengthened during teh project
  • completed research work each week
  • explained why you have performed the particular piece of research work

Students are initially assessed at Week 5, where they will be given a warning if they are not on track. During the final assessment in Wk 10, students will be graded as unsatisfactory if the above criteria are not demonstrated.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4b02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5f02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8702c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Notebook","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The laboratory notebook or equivalent research progress documentation must contain

  • SDS forms or equivalent risk assessments for the beginning of the project and where necessary as the project continues
  • methodologies used in research activities, with enough detail that someone could repeat it
  • brief description of other research work
  • results from all research activities, or clear links to these results
  • in cases where the research actvity did not work, discussion of why this might have occurred
  • in cases where the research activity did work, discussion of what the evidence for this is?
  • consideration of what next once the research activity has succeeeded

The notebook will be assessed as satisfactory or unsatisfactory based on inclusion of all the above elements and evidence of an adequate amount of work. There will be an initial assessment in Wk 5, with a warning given if performance is not adequate. During the final assessment in Wk 10, students will be graded as unsatisfactory if the above criteria are not demonstrated.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4b02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8702c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b202c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961909","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Focus Area: Context","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students need to write a 1-2 page article dedicated to explaining the project context, aimed at first year undergraduates. This report will be due in Wk 11.

To be awarded as satisfactory in the course, student must satisfactorily explore the project context by presenting a scientifically sound report without substantial typographic or grammatical mistakes.

Students will be provided feedback by three markers including their supervisor and one person external to the topic area. For any areas which are judged unsatisfactory, students will be given one opportunity to prepare an improved report (to be submitted by the end of the exam period), otherwise an unsatisfactory grade will be awarded.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM3011","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM3011 - Quantum Nature of Molecules ","description":"

CHEM3011 builds on previous physical chemistry content and deepens students’ understanding and ability to utilise contemporary computational and experimental methods to solve chemical problems. It will explore the phenomenological nature of matter at the quantum scale.  


The course focuses on establishing the theoretical foundations and introducing powerful techniques including symmetry, quantum chemistry, and statistical thermodynamics. The use of modern experimental tools to obtain accurate molecular energies, spectra and thermodynamic data is also described.


Throughout the course, there will be an emphasis on applications of these techniques, for example, in atmospheric chemistry, catalysis and material science.

A significant portion of the assessment will be from workshop activities and take-home assignments. Assignments are typically due on weeks 3, 5, 8 and 10. Feedback will be provided by way of written comments on the completed work or student-initiated meetings.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7590aebadb361c10eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7590aebadb361c10eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7d90aebadb361c10eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f19022fadb361c10eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f590aebadb361c10eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"069022fadb361c10eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Mid-Term Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

A 45 min written test that assesses students' ability to assign point groups, use of character tables to understand spectroscopy, apply appropriate electronic structure methods and basis sets to calculate molecular properties.

\n

The mid-term is typically held in week 5. Feedback will be provided in terms of written comments or student-initiated meetings.

Two hour written exam that assesses students' understanding of symmetry, quantum chemistry and statistical thermodynamics and the application of these theories to calculate molecular properties.

contentlets.description:
CHEM3011 builds on previous physical chemistry content and deepens students’ understanding and ability to utilise contemporary computational and experimental methods to solve chemical problems. It will explore the phenomenological nature of matter at the quantum scale.  

The course focuses on establishing the theoretical foundations and introducing powerful techniques including symmetry, quantum chemistry, and statistical thermodynamics. The use of modern experimental tools to obtain accurate molecular energies, spectra and thermodynamic data is also described.

Throughout the course, there will be an emphasis on applications of these techniques, for example, in atmospheric chemistry, catalysis and material science.

The need for new functional molecules is greater than ever, with ever-growing demand for new therapeutics and materials for the future. The course will focus on developing key skills in making complicated organic molecules from simple building blocks, and transforming one organic molecule to another using the synthetic toolbox. Students will be trained in modern synthetic methodologies and their application in industry to solve real world problems. The concept of retrosynthetic analysis, a logic-based tool that uses pattern recognition and mechanistic understanding for the design of synthetic pathways, will be taught and illustrated with classic case studies, including the synthesis of natural products and bioactive molecules.

contentlets.keywords: chemistry,third year organic chemistry course,chem3021,modern synthetic strategies course
contentlets.description: The need for new functional molecules is greater than ever, with ever-growing demand for new therapeutics and materials for the future. The course will focus on developing key skills in making complicated organic molecules from simple building blocks, and transforming one organic molecule to another using the synthetic toolbox. Students will be trained in modern synthetic methodologies and their application in industry to solve real world problems. The concept of retrosynthetic analysis, a logic-based tool that uses pattern recognition and mechanistic understanding for the design of synthetic pathways, will be taught and illustrated with classic case studies, including the synthesis of natural products and bioactive molecules.
contentlets.title: Organic Chemistry: Modern Synthetic Strategies

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM3031","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM3031 - Inorganic Chemistry: Transition Metals and Complexes","description":"

This course provides insight into the current state-of-art research where metals are used in technologies such as semiconductors, batteries, solar cells, superconductors, and where metals are used in life such as photochemical processes, nitrogen fixation. This course showcases the importance of understanding the role of the metal in these systems. The key components of structural characterization relevant to this understanding are covered and the function derived from the structure expanded. The way chemistry can be used to tune structure and hence properties is shown to underpin all of these technologies and processes in life. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7df0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"5 Practical Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students perform experiments and develop in lab skills (plus some professional skills). Students complete reports on the work they have done.Assessment of the skills that a student develops in lab (formative) and a marked report (summative). Demonstrators tick boxed for the formative skills assessment and write written comments and make corrections to the reports to give a graded score.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3 Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are set assignments that are related to the topics (Metals in life/Technology), they start off with some questions related to the lecture material, and then in the second part the students are then expected to research their individual topic to a greater extent than was covered in lectures before submitting the assignment. The first assignment is formative, the next two are summative. Students must write written reports according to pre-defined guidelines (Rubrics will be used). Reports are corrected and written comments made by the assessors telling students how they can improve in the future (scores also given on Rubric).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a9f0262fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96191b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

Exam is made up of a selection of short and longer written response questions based on laboratory and lecture content. Exam is summative, students receive an overall grade but there is not additional individualised feedback mechanism.

The course is focused on presenting the key principles of medicinal chemistry. It will cover how new drugs are developed, from the design stage to eventual introduction into the clinic, using case studies of successful drugs.  It will emphasise the processes required to optimise chemicals to ensure that they have appropriate drug properties.  Synthesis of new organic molecules is a core skill that lies at the heart of medicinal chemistry and as such, new synhetic methodologies and strategies will be introduced. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"544fe03bdb83d450358b403c3a961910","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Lab Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Lab work is assessed in a variety of ways. There are marks for quality of product and yield, the experimental reports, and discussion / answers to questions where required. The laboratory notebook will be also assessed to ensure students are recording their data in a manner appropriate for protecting intellectual property. It is assessing their ability to use practical Laboratory knowledge and skills in preparing target substances.

Verbal feedback on lab books is provided weekly, while the lab reports will be returned within one week and feedback wil be a combination of marks, and written & verbal advice.

The exam will assess the material covered in topics 2-4. It is assessing the overall level of attainment of knowledge and problem-solving skills in these Topics.

The assessment criteria are based on answers to questions given correctly and that the discussion shows knowledge and understanding of the course. Feedback will be via the final mark for the course.

The test will assess the material covered in topic 1. It is assessing the overall level of attainment of knowledge and problem-solving skills in the Topic

The assessment criteria are based on answers to questions given correctly and that the discussion shows knowledge and understanding of the course. Feedback will be provided in the form of marks and written advice, and will be done so within 2 weeks of the test.

These are three written assignments; one per section of the course.  The assignments provide the students with the opportunity to  use lecture concepts in problem solving and analytical thinking.  They will be awarded marks for problem solving as presented. The assignments will be returned withion 2 weeks of the due date, with feedback based in marks and written advice.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM3061","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM3061 - Chemistry of Materials","description":"

Chemistry is fundamental not just to the design of small molecules, but increasingly to the preparation of materials ranging from hard colloidal nanomaterials to soft complex macromolecular architectures. These materials have been used by humans throughout the ages: from the Lycurgus Cup of ancient Rome to natural polymers such as wool and silk. This course will explore the synthesis and characterisation of such materials, as well as the physical chemistry that underpins their behaviour both in solution and in the solid state. A particular emphasis will be placed on chemistry at the interface, the modification of surfaces, and the self-assembly of block copolymers for the preparation of nanostructures materials.


Lectures and tutorials will be complemented by an integrated laboratory course involving the synthesis of gold nanoparticles and controlled radical polymers, and their combination to prepare stimuli responsive networks. A number of characterisation techniques including NMR, size exclusion chromatography, light scattering and electron microscopy will be taught through the laboratory component.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8eff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a96198f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab Core Skills","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"12","description":"

Students will pass / fail this component by demonstrating an understanding of the characterisation techniques (UV-VIS, DLS, MALS, SEC, NMR, SEM).

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"82ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a96198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2dff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a96195f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"28","description":"

After each experiment, students will submit a lab report, answering problems and discussing the results. Reports will be graded based not on the results obtained, but on how well the student discusses these results, and demonstrates an understanding of the experiment.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"31ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"39ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"75ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7dff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"82ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a96198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b9ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e1ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f5ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f9ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51ff3073db391c50eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research paper assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

1 tutorial / week will be dedicated to discussion of research papers relating to an application area for a application pitch at the end of the term. Students will be assigned to groups to study the provided papers and to find new ones relating to their chosen application area. In week 4, students will need to submit a brief assignment, which answers a couple of questions on the papers and a critical analysis of its strengths and weaknesses, and a paragraph summarising the application pitch they will make at the end of the term (5%). In weeks 9-10 students will present their pitch during scheduled tutorial and turn in a written report (15%). Feedback will be provided throughout the term during tutorials, and after the week 4 assessment and week 9-10 presentations.

contentlets.description:
Chemistry is fundamental not just to the design of small molecules, but increasingly to the preparation of materials ranging from hard colloidal nanomaterials to soft complex macromolecular architectures. These materials have been used by humans throughout the ages: from the Lycurgus Cup of ancient Rome to natural polymers such as wool and silk. This course will explore the synthesis and characterisation of such materials, as well as the physical chemistry that underpins their behaviour both in solution and in the solid state. A particular emphasis will be placed on chemistry at the interface, the modification of surfaces, and the self-assembly of block copolymers for the preparation of nanostructures materials.

Lectures and tutorials will be complemented by an integrated laboratory course involving the synthesis of gold nanoparticles and controlled radical polymers, and their combination to prepare stimuli responsive networks. A number of characterisation techniques including NMR, size exclusion chromatography, light scattering and electron microscopy will be taught through the laboratory component.
contentlets.title: Chemistry of Materials

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM3071","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM3071 - The Chemistry of Catalysis, Systems and Biology","description":"

Building on students' existing background in both organic and inorganic chemistry, this course provides an understanding of the parallels between the function of synthetic and biological molecules, including enzymes, when it comes to catalysis and the formation of complex and self-assembled structures through intermolecular (supramolecular) interactions. In this course you will learn about fundamental concepts and techniques in organic and organometallic catalysis, self-assembly  supramolecular chemistry and the chemistry of biological assemblies and enzymatic catalysis.

Each tutorial will have an associated in-tutorial task or a short questionnaire. In both cases the students will have to demonstrate they can apply the methods covered in the tutorial to solve a task or a problem. Examples include outlining a catalytic pathway, calculate a binding constants or rate constants from experimental data or designing a (bio)chemical system to solve a particular problem such as sensing an analyte.

Environmental Toxicology","description":"

Environmental toxicology is concerned with the toxicological effects of environmental chemicals (both natural and anthropogenic) on living organisms.  This course is an introduction to the field of environmental toxicology through the lens of a chemist.


In this course you will learn about;


  • The classification and properties of toxic substances.
  • The biological properties of important classes of chemical compounds.
  • The fate of xenobiotics in the human body, including detoxification and bioactivation.
  • Chemical transformations of pollutants in the environment; air, water and soil pollution.
  • The methods and processes of analysis of environmental pollutants at trace levels.

You will have opportunity to apply this knowledge by examining and critically assessing case studies and undertaking toxicological testing using analytical instrumentation in the laboratory.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6e724bdbdb6a1010eb6b147a3a9619ca","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The mid session test will consist of 25 multiple choice questions from the introduction to toxicology and Experimental environmental analysis topics.  Specific learning outcomes will be provided in lectures and should be used as a guide to study. Practice questions in the style of those used in the test will be provided on Moodle in advance.

Students will receive feedback in the form of a report highlighting the areas and topics of the test which they answered incorrectly. This feedback will be provided on Moodle a maximum of 7 days after the test.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ee724bdbdb6a1010eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e724bdbdb6a1010eb6b147a3a9619d2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are expected to complete 6 laboratory reports to satify the requirements of the laboratory course. Further details of the laboratory reports for each experiment are available on Moodle and in the lab manual. Exemplar reports and resources to assist you with scientific writing and the analysis and presentation of results are available on Moodle. Reports will be submitted through the Turn It In assignment link on Moodle and detailed marking rubrics for each are available here too.

All lab reports will be marked with a rubric. This will provide students with an indication of the level to which they have been assessed for each section. In addition to this, students will be provided with a short list of suggested action to improve their performance on future submissions. Feedback for lab reports will be provided a maximum of 7 days after the due date. All feedback can be accessed under the turn It In assignment link on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ee724bdbdb6a1010eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76724bdbdb6a1010eb6b147a3a9619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The final exam will consist of short answer questions. All elements of the course will be assessed in the final exam, though a greater weighting will be applied to topics which were not previously assessed in the midterm test. Further details of the distribution of content will be provided in lectures. A practice exam indicative of the style of questions in the exam will be provided on Moodle closer to the exam date.

This is a summative assesment with no formal feedback provided by markers. Nevertheless, students are welcome to contact the course conveynor for feedback on their performance in the final exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ee724bdbdb6a1010eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fe724bdbdb6a1010eb6b147a3a9619fc","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM3901.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

In this course you will learn about;

  • The biological properties of important classes of chemical compounds.
  • The fate of xenobiotics in the human body, including detoxification and bioactivation.

You will have opportunity to apply this knowledge by examining and critically assessing case studies and undertaking toxicological testing using analytical instrumentation in the laboratory.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM3998","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM3998 - Advanced Special Project in Chemistry","description":"

This course provides a more sophisticated introduction to the university research environment than CHEM2999 through undertaking a more complex short research project which utilises the skills and knowledge obtained by students in their early undergraduate degree. The project will be conducted under the direction of a Chemistry academic member of staff taking advantage of UNSW's world-class researchers and research facilities. Student engage directly with academics and their research group, becoming involved with the group's regular activities such as group meetings, while learning important research and transferable graduate skills prized throughout academia, industry and business.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5812c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Focus Area: Future Direction","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students need to write a 1-2 page article dedicated to proposing and exploring future directions of the research. This report will be due in Wk 11.

To be awarded as satisfactory in the course, student must satisfactorily propose and explore the future directions of the research by presenting a scientifically sound report with no substantial typographic or grammatical mistakes.

Students will be provided feedback by three markers including their supervisor and one person external to the topic area. For any areas which are judged unsatisfactory, students will be given one opportunity to prepare an improved report (to be submitted by the end of the exam period), otherwise an unsatisfactory grade will be awarded.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4812c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2702c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students must write a report aimed at the scientifically literate general public. It must contain Abstract, Literature Review and/or Introduction, Project Aims, Methodology, Results, Discussion, Conclusions, References.

The report wil be completed in Week 11 and must satisfactorily address all the below points. Students will be provided feedback by three markers including their supervisor and one person external to the topic area. For any areas which are judged unsatisfactory, students will be given one opportunity to prepare an improved report (to be submitted by the end of the exam period), otherwise an unsatisfactory grade will be awarded.

These points are:

·      Did the abstract adequately summarise the project describing the accomplishments and significance?

·      Did the introduction (literature review) detail the literature and explain the rationale for the project?

·      Did the research project explain what the goal was, and then what was accomplished?

·      Are the techniques/methodology used in the project described and justified?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0c12c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4812c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc12c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3702c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Notebook","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The laboratory notebook or equivalent research progress documentation must contain

  • SDS forms or equivalent risk assessments for the beginning of the project and where necessary as the project continues
  • methodologies used in research activities, with enough detail that someone could repeat it
  • brief description of other research work
  • results from all research activities, or clear links to these results
  • in cases where the research actvity did not work, discussion of why this might have occurred
  • in cases where the research activity did work, discussion of what the evidence for this is?
  • consideration of what next once the research activity has succeeeded

The notebook will be assessed as satisfactory or unsatisfactory based on inclusion of all the above elements and evidence of an adequate amount of work. There will be an initial assessment in Wk 5, with a warning given if performance is not adequate. During the final assessment in Wk 10, students will be graded as unsatisfactory if the above criteria are not demonstrated

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc12c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fb02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Summary Document","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Definition:

Research Activity: Task performed by the student that produces original material or data to contribute to the project objectives.  This original material or data may include chemicals, computer programs, spectra, interview transcripts, calculation results, questions, analysis, collation and more.

Research Work: Task performed by the student in order to fulfil the project objectives. This includes both research activities as defined above and those tasks required to prepare for research activities, for example, literature review, learning new synthetic, instrumental or computational technique and learning new scientific content knowledge.

Assessment Task:

Summary of Research Work and Activity often in spreadsheet form, which must include identification of Date, Activity, Research Skills demonstrated/ acquired and Transferable Skills/ Graduate Attributes demonstrated/ acquired.

Grading comments:

To be awarded as satisfactory, the summary document must contain evidence that the student has:

  • learnt new research skills during the project
  • identified relevant transferable skills that you have developed and/or strengthened during teh project
  • completed research work each week
  • explained why you have performed the particular piece of research work

Students are initially assessed at Week 5, where they will be given a warning if they are not on track. During the final assessment in Wk 10, students will be graded as unsatisfactory if the above criteria are not demonstrated.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8412c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc12c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fb02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"eb02c5b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96196f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM3998.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course provides a more sophisticated introduction to the university research environment than CHEM2999 through undertaking a more complex short research project which utilises the skills and knowledge obtained by students in their early undergraduate degree. The project will be conducted under the direction of a Chemistry academic member of staff taking advantage of UNSW's world-class researchers and research facilities. Student engage directly with academics and their research group, becoming involved with the group's regular activities such as group meetings, while learning important research and transferable graduate skills prized throughout academia, industry and business.
contentlets.title: Advanced Special Project in Chemistry

contentlets.description: Designed for those with a higher level of preparedness in Chemistry. A multifaceted course that will give students a high level of basic research skills, especially in critical evaluation of data and communication of results, but with a specialised focus on Chemistry. Consists of a selection of lectures and seminars on advanced topics in Chemistry and a research project.
contentlets.title: Advanced Chemistry 4 Honours

contentlets.description: Designed for those with broad interests in Science but with a wish to specialise in Chemistry. A varied program that will give students a high level of basic research skills, with emphasis on the critical evaluation of data and communication of results. Consists of a limited series of lectures and and seminars on advanced topics in Chemistry, a literature review and research project on a major topic outside the review area.
contentlets.title: Chemical Sciences 4 (Honours)

contentlets.description: This Honours year is designed specifically for students enrolled in the Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry program. It provides a truly interdisciplinary and collaborative experience with a strong emphasis on basic research skills, from modelling and synthesis through to evaluation of biological activity. Other essential skills such as interpretation of data and presentation techniques are integrated throughout the course. The Honours year consists of a major research project, series of lectures on contemporary chemistry and pharmacology, as well as seminars on relevant professional and ethical topics.Note: Honours consists of 48 UoC taken over two sessions each consisting of 24 UoC.
contentlets.title: Honours in Medicinal Chemistry

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CHEM4501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM4501 - Chemistry Project Proposal and Research Skills","description":"

Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory. Over the course of 3 terms, 48 UoC are taken and this course represents 6 UoC of research skills and development of the proposal. The research is directed by an academic or equivalent in the School of Chemistry and comprises original research. The skills are developed via online modules, during face-to-face lectures with the Honours coordinator or equivalent and by attending research Seminars delivered by research visitors to UNSW.


Other required research training, including relevant workplace health and safety inductions and additional instruction on topics including preparation of research proposals, and ethical practice, complements this course. The course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Chemistry Honours Program. The School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8186513fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Health and Safety / Ethics Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students need to demonstrate competence in workplace health and safety and ethics relevant to professional practice as a research chemist.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3486513fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c986513fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2086513fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

The project proposal is the major piece of work submitted for this 6 UOC introductory Honours course.  It will consist of a review of relevant literature and a proposal of work to be carried out during the Honours year.


Feedback is provided within a week following the assessment.

Students are required to give a short seminar based on their written proposal, and answer questions on their presentation.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

Feedback is provided within a week following the assessment.

contentlets.description:
Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory. Over the course of 3 terms, 48 UoC are taken and this course represents 6 UoC of research skills and development of the proposal. The research is directed by an academic or equivalent in the School of Chemistry and comprises original research. The skills are developed via online modules, during face-to-face lectures with the Honours coordinator or equivalent and by attending research Seminars delivered by research visitors to UNSW.

Other required research training, including relevant workplace health and safety inductions and additional instruction on topics including preparation of research proposals, and ethical practice, complements this course. The course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Chemistry Honours Program. The School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.
contentlets.title: Chemistry Project Proposal and Research Skills

Medicinal Chemistry Honours coursework is designed to provide students with advanced knowledge relevant to the discipline of Medicinal Chemistry.  The course will cover topics of contemporary interest including the drug development process, advanced reaction mechanisms for modern organic synthesis, and synthesis and use of radiolabelled pharmaceuticals. 


The Medicinal Chemistry program coordinator must approve enrolment.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"707585ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961904","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Within the course students will study 3 electives and each will have an assignment or other piece of continuous assessment typically worth 40% of the elective.


Students will have their annotated and corrected assignments returned to them.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"387545ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"747585ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f87545ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a47545ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

At the conclusion of the lectures students will sit a 2 hour examination covering all areas of the course. 


Students will be advised of their final mark for the course which will incorporate their exam result.

The Medicinal Chemistry program coordinator must approve enrolment.

Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory. Over the course of 3 terms, 48 UoC are taken and this course represents 6 UoC of research. The research is directed by an academic or equivalent in the School of Chemistry and comprises original research.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Chemistry Honours Program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.

At the conclusion of their Honours project  (i.e. at the conclusion of the entire 36 UOC), following submission of the thesis, students are required to give a formal seminar.  The duration of the oral examination is up to 20 minutes, followed by a period of questions.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.


Not specified","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3fa17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a3a17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"57a17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96193a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

At the conclusion of their Honours project (i.e. at the conclusion of the entire 36 UOC), following submission of the thesis, students are required to give a formal seminar and also sit an oral examination, conducted by up to 4 academics from the School (the supervisor cannot be one of these four members of staff).  The duration of the oral examination is up to 30 minutes.

contentlets.description:
Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory. Over the course of 3 terms, 48 UoC are taken and this course represents 6 UoC of research. The research is directed by an academic or equivalent in the School of Chemistry and comprises original research.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Chemistry Honours Program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.

Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory. Over the course of 3 terms, 48 UoC are taken and this course represents 12 UoC of research. The research is directed by an academic or equivalent in the School of Chemistry and comprises original research.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Chemistry Honours Program, and the School’s Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.

At the conclusion of their Honours project (i.e. at the conclusion of the entire 36 UOC), following submission of the thesis, students are required to give a formal seminar and also sit an oral examination, conducted by up to 4 academics from the School (the supervisor cannot be one of these four members of staff).  The duration of the oral examination is up to 30 minutes.

At the conclusion of their Honours project  (i.e. at the conclusion of the entire 36 UOC), following submission of the thesis, students are required to give a formal seminar.  The duration of the oral examination is up to 20 minutes, followed by a period of questions.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM4524 - Chemistry Honours Project 24 UOC","description":"

This course is designed for students undertaking a full-time Honours year as part of the Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry (Honours) or undertaking Honours in the School of Chemistry.  The Honours year allows students to undertake a supervised Research Project under the direction of an academic staff member, where the project introduces students to research and places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge.  Over the course of the Honours project the student will gain experience in the use of specialised research techniques relevant to their chosen area, critical thinking, data collection and analysis, problem solving and scientific communication.  Assessment tasks include the submission of a Research Thesis based on substantial independent research activity.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Chemistry Honours Program or the Medicinal Chemistry Honours program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.

At the conclusion of their Honours project, following submission of the thesis, students are required to give a formal seminar and also sit an oral examination, conducted by up to 4 academics from the School (the supervisor cannot be one of these four members of staff).  The duration of the oral examination is up to 30 minutes.

This course is designed for students undertaking a full-time Honours year as part of the Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry (Honours) or undertaking Honours in the School of Chemistry.  The Honours year allows students to undertake a supervised Research Project under the direction of an academic staff member, where the project introduces students to research and places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge.  Over the course of the Honours project the student will gain experience in the use of specialised research techniques relevant to their chosen area, critical thinking, data collection and analysis, problem solving and scientific communication.  Assessment tasks include the submission of a Research Thesis based on substantial independent research activity.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Chemistry Honours Program or the Medicinal Chemistry Honours program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.
