","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CHEM6041","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM6041 - Advanced Instrumental Analysis","description":"

This course builds on students' existing background in analytical chemistry to develop both theory and practice relating to the latest analytical techniques used in industry and research. The course covers in general, method validation and quality assurance in the analytical chemistry laboratory; and for selected major techniques, method development, theory, operation, instrumentation and applications. Analytical methods covered include separation techniques (chromatography), mass spectrometry, hyphenated chromatography-mass spectrometry techniques, electrochemistry, NMR (including 2D NMR), and elemental analysis, which are amongst the most widely used analytical instrumental techniques across a broad range of disciplines and in many different industries. The course was designed in close consultation with industry leaders (who will also give guest lectures) to provide valuable perspectives from outside academia and provide focus on the most relevant occupational skills. Students will obtain hands-on experience using state-of-the art, instruments in the Mark Wainwright Analytical Centre. Thus, the course strongly emphasises employability in both industry, government and academy.
 


NOTE: Postgraduate coursework students wishing to enrol in this course should contact the The School of Chemistry www.chem.unsw.edu.au for advice to arrange enrolment.   

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3f4343d4db2b2c10fe4b322af49619e2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Summative report of capstone experiment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

This report will summaries the key findings and recommendations from the capstone project.

  • Students will be assessed individually on their contribution to chemical analysis and presentation of data and self-reflection.
  • Students will present a 10 minute talk to their peers on a specific analytical technique and the results they obtained. 
  • Students will be assessed as a group on the initial proposal and project plan, executive summary, conclusions and recommendations from the report.

Formative Feedback:

Students will be provided with the opportunity early in the capstone phase of the unit to present a project plan and analysis timeline to the teaching team who will provide feedback to improve and develop the proposal to a working state.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b74343d4db2b2c10fe4b322af49619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bb4343d4db2b2c10fe4b322af49619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"045383d4db2b2c10fe4b322af4961909","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This exam will be in two parts.

1. Students will be provided with a scenario and problem requiring analytical chemistry to resolve. Students will be required to propose the appropriate analytical approach given the context, to solve the problem.

2. Students will be provided with a real industry report and be required to compose an executive dot-point summary and list of recommendations for a non expert audience.

contentlets.description:
This course builds on students' existing background in analytical chemistry to develop both theory and practice relating to the latest analytical techniques used in industry and research. The course covers in general, method validation and quality assurance in the analytical chemistry laboratory; and for selected major techniques, method development, theory, operation, instrumentation and applications. Analytical methods covered include separation techniques (chromatography), mass spectrometry, hyphenated chromatography-mass spectrometry techniques, electrochemistry, NMR (including 2D NMR), and elemental analysis, which are amongst the most widely used analytical instrumental techniques across a broad range of disciplines and in many different industries. The course was designed in close consultation with industry leaders (who will also give guest lectures) to provide valuable perspectives from outside academia and provide focus on the most relevant occupational skills. Students will obtain hands-on experience using state-of-the art, instruments in the Mark Wainwright Analytical Centre. Thus, the course strongly emphasises employability in both industry, government and academy.
 

NOTE: Postgraduate coursework students wishing to enrol in this course should contact the The School of Chemistry www.chem.unsw.edu.au for advice to arrange enrolment.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3f4343d4db2b2c10fe4b322af49619e2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Summative report of capstone experiment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

This report will summaries the key findings and recommendations from the capstone project.

  • Students will be assessed individually on their contribution to chemical analysis and presentation of data and self-reflection.
  • Students will present a 10 minute talk to their peers on a specific analytical technique and the results they obtained. 
  • Students will be assessed as a group on the initial proposal and project plan, executive summary, conclusions and recommendations from the report.

Formative Feedback:

Students will be provided with the opportunity early in the capstone phase of the unit to present a project plan and analysis timeline to the teaching team who will provide feedback to improve and develop the proposal to a working state.

It is aimed as an alternative to 6041 for those students unable to be present for face-to-face content due to the exceptional circumstances such as the global pandemic.


This course builds on students' existing background in analytical chemistry to develop both theory and practice relating to the latest analytical techniques used in industry and research. This course builds on students' existing background in analytical chemistry to develop both theory and practice relating to the latest analytical techniques used in industry and research. The course covers in general, method validation and quality assurance in the analytical chemistry laboratory; and for selected major techniques, method development, theory, operation, instrumentation and applications. Topics in contemporary Chemistry A is a premier lecture course run by the School of Chemistry. The course runs in term 1 and can be taken as a stand alone course or as a complement to CHEM6702 (the term 2 partner to this course). The course will emphasise some of the latest advances in chemistry, including several topics based on current research directions of the School. Students will study three topics. The topics will vary depending on availability and will differ from, and complement, those offered in the following CHEM6702 course. Students should check with the course coordinator which topics will be offered.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CHEM7001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM7001 - Chemical Safety & Legislation","description":"

An understanding of workplace safety issues is important for students pursuing careers in the chemical industry. This course explores the legal frameworks, current methodologies and issues of best practice in the risk minimisation and management of workplace hazards. The subject uses a variety of media in online delivery of course material and assessment, including recorded lectures, websites, videos and documented case studies. It is anticipated that students will gain an appreciation of current legislation and codes of practice, identify different types of chemical workplace hazards and be able to apply risk management to workplace hazards.

Students will be required to prepare a risk assessment and safe work procedure for a hypothetical high-risk chemistry experiment.

Students will be required to achieve a satisfactory grade in order to pass this component.

Following the introductory component, students will be asked to prepare a report on a major chemical industry disaster and relevant measures that were taken to address immediate hazards. Students will be required to achieve a satisfactory grade in order to pass this component.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4e5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"565791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"925791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c25791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"715791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case study 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are to provide a short report on a major chemical industry accident that brought about major changes to regulation/legislation that benefited consumers, the environment and industry. For this assignment, students will be given a number of topics to choose from, one of which we have identified to be the 1976 Seveso disaster which prompted the introduction of the Seveso Directive.

Students will be required to achieve a satisfactory grade in order to pass this component.

This course covers a range of important skills necessary for students entering a research career in Chemistry. Topics covered in the course include: occupational health and safety, database and library usage including use of current database searching tools, project planning and experimental design, report writing techniques, production of a research proposal, presentation skills, and use of chemistry-related software. Enrolment requires the approval of the School.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CHEM7998","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CHEM7998 - Special Project in Chemistry","description":"

This research project course introduces postgraduate students to research. They acquire skills of being a research focused laboratory working on cutting edge science and learning the parameters that a researcher faces. It also provides hands on training in an academic laboratory and the use of various methodologies and equipment depending on the research project. The intention is to provide a whole research experience with a dedicated project. Students will learn aspects such as project planning, literature review, project development, oral and written and reporting.


Please note this course is designed specifically for students who take the Professional Masters of Science. The course may be used for coursework for other postgraduate programmes (at the discretion of the programme authority).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"655791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will write a 14 page (double spaced) including 1 cover page report on their research project. The structure will be based on their area of research but will generally contain an abstract, introduction, results and discussion and conclusions section. Some questions the students should consider include:

·  Did abstract adequately summarize the project describing the accomplishments and significance?

·  Did the introduction detail the literature and explain the rationale for the project?

·  Did the report explain what was the goal and then what was accomplished? 

·  Did the conclusion indicate what steps need to be taken in the future?

·  Did the report explain how the experiments could have been improved?

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"195791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1d5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"695791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d95791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"015791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Notebook","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to submit a copy of their notebook in Week 5 (or halfway through) on which they will be provided feedback. Using this feedback they will submit a final notebook in Week 10 (final week). The lab-book will detail:

Literature that is being used to design experiments

How the experiments are being run and why?

Detailed experimental conditions/parameters to allow others to repeat the work.

Figures and data from measurements

Discussion on why an experiment worked or not

Plans for future steps

Note the notebook can be either hardcover or electronic.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"195791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1d5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9d5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d95791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"455791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Excel diary","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be required to submit a research summary using a template provided. This is designed to summarise the research undertaken and will consist of:

·  Where to find the experiments with reference to the notebook (page?)

·  Time allocated to techniques and literature

·  Types of experiments conducted

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"195791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1d5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9d5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d95791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8d5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Supervisor Evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The students will be required to work for approximately 8 hrs per week or equivalent. The supervisor will provide a mark based on:

·  Did the student show up at the scheduled time and did they work in the lab?

·  Was the student attentive when being trained?

Did the student perform work independently by the end of the course?   

 This mark will be moderated by the course coordinator in order to ensure consistency within the cohort and over the years the course is run.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"195791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"695791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9d5791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c55791bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961909","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CHEM7998.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

They acquire skills of being a research focused laboratory working on cutting edge science and learning the parameters that a researcher faces. It also provides hands on training in an academic laboratory and the use of various methodologies and equipment depending on the research project. The intention is to provide a whole research experience with a dedicated project. Students will learn aspects such as project planning, literature review, project development, oral and written and reporting.

Please note this course is designed specifically for students who take the Professional Masters of Science. The course may be used for coursework for other postgraduate programmes (at the discretion of the programme authority).
contentlets.title: Special Project in Chemistry
